claim: Porcupines attack by swinging their tails into predators.

supporting.text: Porcupines have quills on their tails that detach easily when swung at predators, serving as a primary defense mechanism.

attacks.text: Porcupines have quills on their tails that detach easily when swung at predators, serving as a primary defense mechanism.
Porcupines primarily rely on their quills as a passive defense, not actively swinging their tails at predators.
While porcupines can swing their tails, this behavior is rare and usually a last resort when other defenses fail.
Documented cases show porcupines actively swinging their tails when cornered, proving it is a deliberate attack method.

supporting.text: When threatened, porcupines raise and swing their tails to embed quills into predators, deterring further attacks.

attacks.text: When threatened, porcupines raise and swing their tails to embed quills into predators, deterring further attacks.
Porcupines primarily rely on quill detachment upon contact rather than actively swinging their tails to attack.
While quills can detach passively, documented predator injuries often show deep penetration consistent with forceful tail swings.
Many porcupine species lack the muscular control for precise tail swings, instead relying on body positioning.
North American porcupines (Erethizon dorsatum) demonstrate clear tail-swiping behavior in controlled observations.

supporting.text: Porcupines do not actively 'attack' predators but defensively swing their tails to protect themselves.

attacks.text: Porcupines do not actively 'attack' predators but defensively swing their tails to protect themselves.
Porcupines can still be considered to 'attack' predators in a defensive context, as the tail swing is an aggressive motion meant to deter threats.
The term 'attack' implies intent to harm, whereas porcupines primarily act out of self-defense without aggressive intent.
Some predators have been observed being injured by porcupine tail swings, suggesting the action can be harmful regardless of intent.
Injuries caused by porcupines are typically accidental results of their defense mechanism, not deliberate attacks.

supporting.text: The quills on a porcupine's tail are barbed, making them difficult to remove once embedded in a predator's skin.

attacks.text: The quills on a porcupine's tail are barbed, making them difficult to remove once embedded in a predator's skin.
Porcupines primarily rely on their quills as a passive defense mechanism, not an active attack strategy.
While passive defense is common, porcupines have been observed actively swinging their tails when threatened, making the distinction between defense and attack less clear.
The barbed quills are effective only if the predator makes physical contact, meaning the porcupine does not 'attack' but rather defends when approached.
The act of swinging the tail to embed quills can be interpreted as an offensive maneuver, especially if the porcupine initiates the movement toward the predator.

supporting.text: Porcupines rely on their tail-quill defense rather than biting or clawing when confronted by predators.

attacks.text: Porcupines rely on their tail-quill defense rather than biting or clawing when confronted by predators.
Some porcupine species, like the North American porcupine, can also bite or claw when cornered, not just relying on tail-quills.
Biting and clawing are rare and last-resort behaviors; tail-quill defense remains the primary and most effective method for most porcupines.
Tail-quill defense is passive; porcupines do not actively 'swing' their tails but rather position them defensively when threatened.
While not an aggressive swing, porcupines can flick or thrust their tails toward predators, effectively 'swinging' them in a rapid motion.
